Blog.post: FROM APRIL 24, 2003: So last night was nothing exciting, just some regulars-- who were not enlightening. We have a new waitress and Imani's her name. I asked if she was like Iman, of model fame. She threw back her hair and haughtily said, "Are you comparing me to her?Â I'd rather be dead!" So she is a model too, and super thin, It's really ridiculous because she eats nothin' We have a chocolate garnish that we use for a drink an entire piece (1 ounce!) would not pass the brink of her lips.Â Well, in fact, she refuses to eat carbs, dairy, and primarily meats. When she ordered dinner at the end of the shift, the kitchen almost killed her with all her bullsh#t. She wanted vegetables steamed, which we don't really do, But the kitchen appeased her when she became unglued. As for me, I laughed and ate, my chicken ceasar with great appetate. There were no gypsies, I'm happy to say. But there were 'tutes galore working the business way. Overall my anger was most directed, at two business women who had neglected to develop any social skills. If this was the 50s, I would say they were pills. One, in particular, had such a big head She owned a limo-- that's enough said. Then these two ladies went onto get bombed even though I short-poured them all night long. Without doubt, the best part of the night, was when they bonded with the hookers-- they had no insight. Then they laid on the tables and danced in the lounge, and bothered my customers with cigarettes they scrounged. One of them had the gall to say, That I was no fun.Â Can you believe it- ey? I just smiled at their silly jest, andcharged them again.Â A bartender knows best. But the worst part: that with a corporate card 10% they left me-- those annoying ba#tards! But I had the last laugh when it came to the end, one left her palm pilot on the bar by her friend. As soon as they left, I took it from the seat, and put it in the trash-- my revenge complete. So if there is one thing to be gleaned from this night, it's be nice to your bartender.Â She has unknown might.

FROM AUGUST 18, 2003 Hi Ladies- I am not having a good morning.Â I just lost the e-mail that I was writing to you, and it was almost finished.Â That e-mail started with cheerful banter, but now I am going to cut right to the chase.Â I hate fu^k#ng Wednesdays. WHAT I HAVE LEARNED ABOUT GUYS WHILE TENDING BAR 1.Â Beware of men who go to bars by themselves on a regular basis.Â Most of the guys I name in my e-mails fall into this category.Â I know that I sometimes say that so-and-so is not a bad guy.Â By this, I mean that he is not psychotic and listening to him ramble doesn't make me want to jab a beer bottle into my eye.Â But under no circumstances would I hang out with him outside of the bar. 2.Â If a guy is mildly obnoxious when he is hitting on you-- watch out.Â That was him trying to make a good impression. 3.Â Things that sketch me out in male customers: shirts that are half-way unbuttoned, muscle shirts, removing wedding rings, and buying a girl a shot when she can barely stand. 4.Â If your boyfriend goes to a bar, you have two choices, go with him or stay home.Â If you decide to stay home, do NOT repeatedly call him and ask him exactly what he is doing. 5.Â Guys who pull out chairs for ladies or stand when they leave the table are smooth or super-smooth. 6.Â If a guy is hitting on you and offers to buy you a drink, this can mean one of two things.Â a)Â He is a decent guy and this is what decent guys do.Â b)Â He wants to get you drunk and take advantage of you.Â Assume B. 7.Â If a guy is hitting on you and doesn't offer to buy you a drink, this can mean only one thing, -- he is a cheap ba$tard. 8.Â If a guy is on a date and asks how much all of the drinks are before ordering them, he is an idiot.Â He is not stupid because he is worried about the money, but, rather, because he wasn't smart enough to ask for a drink menu so that he doesn't look like a cheap ba$tard. 9.Â Guys who treat women well also tip well.Â There are no exceptions to this rule. 10.Â Fact:Â I have never seen a man under 35 go home with a 'tute. 11.Â If a guy is out all night at a bar and doesn't come home, he probably cheated on you. 12.Â I often see pretty girls get picked up by unattractive guys.Â I rarely see unattractive women go home with hot men.Â Question:Â Are beer goggles more of a female phenomena? 13.Â Â If a man tells you how much money he makes in the first ten minutes of conversation, run away from him as fast as you can. 14.Â Guys who use cheesy pick-up lines seriously or hit on the bartender are often the most confident men in the room, even if that confidence is often misplaced. 15.Â What a guy's drink says about him: --Beer:Â He is a man's man, and he is easy to please.Â There is also the possibility that he is stupid or unsophisticated. -- Aged Scotch:Â He is wealthy and pretentious or dreams of being so. --Â Martini:Â He likes to drink almost as much as he likes telling people what to do.Â (I'll have that chilled with grey goose, up, with three olives.) -- Any liquor + diet coke: He is fat. -- Vodka + red bull:Â He thinks that he is having sex later. -- Hypnotic, red wine with ice, or a white wine spritzer:Â He has no taste --Shots:Â He is in a hurry 16.Â Fact:Â The bachelorette parties that I have witnessed have been wilder than the bachelor parties that I have seen. 17.Â When women get up and start the dance party, it is cute.Â When men do it, it is sort of pathetic. 18.Â Beware of the guy who has a $3,000 suit and really screwed up teeth (This applies to many of the customers at my bar.)Â He obviously has weird priorities. 19.Â A man is much less likely to return a drink to a bartender than a woman is. 20.Â Men are better tippers.Â It's sad, but true. 21.Â Men who are doing "business" while sitting at a bar are employed in a shady industry. 22.Â When a man wants to start a tab but can't provide a credit card it probably means that he doesn't have a valid credit card. 23.Â When men are at a work function, they are much less likely than women to make idiots of themselves in front of their co-workers. 24.Â Forms of polite interaction between men and women that still should occur in bars, -- letting the girl order first. --Â letting the girl get the first glass of wine --Â helping the girl if she is choking (Last night, I had to run out from behind the bar and pat a girl on the back because she was choking and her bf wasn't doing anything) 25.Â Fact:Â I have never had a guy admit to me that his girlfriend broke up with him.Â He has always claimed that it was mutual or that he did the breaking up. 26.Â If a guy is at a bar watching a sporting event, he doesn't want to talk to you.Â He really wants to watch the sporting event.Â The only exception to this would be if you looked like Molly Simms or Heidi Klum (sp?). 27.Â All good looking, full-time male bartenders are players and can't be trusted. 28.Â The most bad a#s drink that a guy can order is a vodka on the rocks with no fruit or a gin martini. 29.Â Do not be impressed if a bartender knows the guy that you are on the date with.Â He probably spends too much time in that bar.Â See reason #1. 30.Â I hate to say it, but men are much better bar customers than women. That's about it, ladies.Â I do have one important announcement to make. THIS SUNDAY, AUGUST 16TH, IS THE ULTIMATE BAR TRIVIA SHOW DOWN.Â WE WILL BEGIN OUR MARCH TO VICTORY AT AT 8:00.Â GO A-TEAM!

FROM 7/23/03 Good Morning Ladies: How are you on this miserable rainy morning? I am getting a late start on this e-mail because when I came to work this morning the "s" and "w" keys were stuck on my computer. Rather than wait until the techie people came in so that they could fix it, I decided to try to respond to a bunch of e-mails without using those letters. Am I crazy?? My name begins with a capital S for goodness sakes. Luckily, when I began to pound on the keys in frustration, they became unstuck. So having overcome technology's attempt to thwart me, I'll move onto the recap. I think that the main reason that I write these recaps is because I can't believe the things that I am witnessing. In other words, I sometimes have to take a step back and say to myself, "Yes, me, a naive Catholic girl from Pennsylvania, is hearing a h*oker joke with a customer about the blo#w jo$ she just gave him in the bathroom." I find that I must tell these random events to others because I don't want to be the only one whose morals have been corrupted. When I see the event that I just described above, my most common reaction now is, "Well, at least the 'tute will have a lot of cash. She'll probably tip me well." But last night, even I was a little bit shocked or grossed out by the events that transpired at TheBar. It all started when Jack came into work and asked me if I liked pork. Not suspecting anything, I went on about my deep regard for bacon. He told me that this was very good because he was armed with bags of food that he had cooked for select members of the staff. He cornered me and told me in no uncertain terms that I shouldn't order dinner from the kitchen later that night because he would give me some of his food. Now, I tried to back out of this as gracefully as I could, mostly because my stomach never responds well to untried foods. However, Jack was adamant, and I didn't want to hurt his feelings. I agreed to try his food, but I silently planned to throw out most of it. Around midnight, I told Jack that I wanted to eat, and I thought that he was going to take me to the kitchen. Unfortunately, Jack told me that I couldn't eat there as I usually did because he didn't make enough for the kitchen staff. So he took me to the little room where we keep our stereo, gave me a plate full of food, and shut the door. Now, there is no other exit to this room, and Jack was standing outside by the trash can. I knew that I was going to have to make a go of it, and eat some of the concoction before me. The rice wasn't bad, but the pork was horrendous. After holding my nose and shoveling down about five pieces of it, I remembered something else that Jack had said earlier in the night; he couldn't afford to get a hair cut. It suddenly occurred to me in that if Jack couldn't afford to get a five dollar hair cut, he probably couldn't afford to buy high quality pork. I abruptly stopped eating, went outside, and I told Jack that I was full and he should wrap the rest up. Unfortunately, he actually did wrap it up for me, and, after closing, he chased me down in my cab to give it back to me after I had "left" it behind. It's really amazing how the smell of Bengledeshian pork can ruin a perfectly good cab ride. The customers last night were an absolute joke. The longer I bartend, the more bitter I become that I have to listen to these drunks whine on and on about their problems. (Yes, I do realize the irony that I am whining here. But you are voluntarily reading!) What I really don't understand is that the people who complain about their problems to me are not the ones who should be complaining. For example, I have never heard a 'tute complain about her lot in life, but I can't tell you how many businessmen whine to me about the market. For one night, I would like to tell the whiners the answers to, or what I really think of, their problems. I'll use one of my least favorite customers, Matthew, as an example. I am using him because a lot of you met him last week. He was the random guy sitting in the corner on Tuesday. I guess he felt shy in the ladies' presence, because he kept his big mouth shut that day. Last night, I was not so lucky. First he began by telling me how badly his business has been doing and how he is losing money. My solution to this problem: Stop spending $100+ at Merchant's five nights a week. I refuse to feel sorry for someone who b+tches to me when we are out of Grey Goose so he can't pay $11 for a martini. Another big complaint of Matthew's is women. He complains that he doesn't understand them. However, this is also the man who told me that he takes women out on 15 minute dates. If he doesn't like something in the first 15 minutes, he abruptly ends it. Ahhh... if only I had that power of discretion over my customers, he wouldn't have made it through the door. But my absolute least favorite thing about Matthew is the way that he comments on my life. He always makes inferences to the fact that, though I am much "better educated" (his words) than him, he is making a lot more money than me. What forty-something year old man rubs it in a twenty-something girl's face about how much money he makes? Last night, I mentioned that I was thinking of applying to law school. (Note* this was extremely stupid on my part. Normally, I never tell hated customers anything about my life.) He asked me why I didn't just want to" get married and raise a family, like most girls." I told him that I was suprised I hadn't snatched someone like him up yet. I don't think that he got the irony. But the absolute highlight of the night is was what I will henceforth call my page 6 moment. Two 'tutes came into the bar around 2:00. Fee and H: You may remember the one as the friend of the crazy 'tute from Saturday. Anyway, I will just put it out there that I am not mistaken about what these ladies did for a living. They were sitting at a bar when this random guy sat down next to them. He immediately pi#sed me off because he sat down, lit up a cigar, and orderd a glass of water. Come one, taking up my bar stool, polluting the air with cigar smoke, and not tipping me breaks all proper customer credos. Anyway, he told me that he comes there a lot, but I was tuning him out. He then began to talk to the 'tutes. He asked them outright if they were working, and they said, "Yes." They asked if he was interested, but he said no because he was a STATE ASSEMBLYMAN. However, I think this pillar of the community changed his mind later in the evening. He eventually started to drink, and he offered to buy them shots, but they declined. Then, he demanded that he they tell him a dirty joke, and they said that they could "show" him one outside. Shortly thereafter, they all left the bar. I'll leave you to draw your own conclusions. Anyway ladies, that's all the news here. I hope that you are all well, and I'll talk to you soon-

FROM 9/10/03 Hi Everyone- Have you all noticed what time I am composing this recap?Â It's almost ten in the morning, and I just got in.Â Because my boss is quite possibly the greatest woman in the world, she agreed that I can come in at 10 on Wednesday mornings.Â (Insert wild, enthusiastic applause here). After getting four hours of sleep, I feel like I could run ten miles, or, at the very least, stare at this computer for eight hours without nodding off. FIrst of all, I would like to give a big thank you shout-out to Kellyfor coming by the bar last night.Â It was great to see you.Â I couldn't tell you this while you were there, but you were very close to making a love connection.Â Do you remember that group of guys at the bar?Â They aren't hard to remember because they were my only other customers at that time.Â Anyway, the youngest one, i.e. the one in his early forties, thought you were quite the little studette.Â He seemed pissed when Tom came, but, don't worry, I assured him that he was not your boyfriend.Â I am hoping that I can arrange forÂ a way for the two of you to meet.Â He is full of great lines like asking me, "So... are you into girls?" and, to his friend, "I'm telling you, your daughter's friends are hot."Â Don't worry, Kelly.Â I promise to pursue this promising catch for you.Â This sort of thing is all part of the bar's motto.Â My bar:Â Bringing people together for the better, but usually for the worse. I do have to update you all on a bit of bar gossip.Â We have a new customer that has been 86ed/banned fromt he bar- Mart.Â Now, I know that most of you have met Mart.Â FF:Â He is the guy that bet you a grand that you couldn't drink a martini an hour for the rest of the night.Â Everyone else:Â Do you remember when you came in with Little H?Â He was the guy that was sitting in the corner.Â Apparently, on Monday night, Mart used his charm and boyish good looks... or money to convince one of our lovely female patrons to give him a bl#w jo in the back room.Â Klassy!Â Apparently, both Jack and Bergen walked in on him, and now he is banned.Â The only saving grace to this story is that he didn't come in last night so I didn't have to break the news to him! Do you remember the guy that I threw out three times in one night and then he hid in the men's room?Â Well, my bar is apparently his new favorite hang out.Â He was there again last night.Â Both Bergen and I don't like him.Â He got drunk and kept accusing us of talking about him... which was essentially true.Â Some woman came in to see him for a little bit.Â The best part of my night was when she stood up, yelled at him, and then stormed out of the bar.Â Take that, Captain Urinal. Other than that, I don't have too much to report.Â Have a great day, and I'll probably see a lot of you tomorrow-

FROM 9/3/03: Hi Ladies-- How are you doing?Â Just think:Â Only two more days until the week-end.Â For those of you that don't know, that title refers to Jack and his response every time you ask him how he is doing. So... last night was quite an excellent night by the bar's standards.Â The first good thing that happened last night was that Penny continued to train withÂ me.Â It's always pleasant to have some company behind the bar, and she is still doing an excellent job. The night go to a rip-roaring good start when the new, female manager Ollyman (pronounced something like OL- LEE - MON) asked MY permission to leave before close.Â I was basically like, "Sure, that would be fine with me."Â Is she crazy?Â Half of the time, a manager just leaves me there without aÂ goodbye or his card to void things. Then, two other bartenders came in to booze for a bit.Â Ollyman joined them and before I knew it, the three of them were bombed.Â There was one customer there that I didn't like (for those of you that really follow these, he was the guy that I threw out three times and then he hid in the men's bathroom), and one of the bartenders, Jan, began to berate him.Â He told Bergen that his glass was dirty, and Jan yelled across the bar, "You're lucky that we don't spit in it."Â Yowsers! Other than that, I just had a lot of quality customers.Â A group from a local bar left me a ton of money, and so did this random guy with a 'tute.Â Actually, the latter was a pretty funny scene.Â The couple consisted of a late-twenty-year-old 'tute and a mid-fifty-year-old married man.Â Well, he had a ring anyway.Â At one point in the evening, he turned to his companion and said, "I am going to ask you three questions, How old do you think I am?Â How old do you think I feel at heart, and how old do you think I will seem later tonight?"Â I guess that lady was going to be earning her dough that evening. That's about all that's new.Â Barring unforseen circumstances, penny and I should be closing upstairs on Saturday.Â Feel free to stop by. PT:Â Did I miss anything?

FROM 8/27/03: Hi Everybody- Another Wednesday, another recap.Â How is everyone doing today? First things first:Â I don't know if all of you know this, but Penny is training with me behind the bar.Â That's right; I am imparting all of my worldly, bartending wisdom to another in hopes that she can join me in my seedy part-time job and contribute to these e-mails.Â For her first time, Penny was absolutely amazing.Â How are you feeling today? Thanks also to KC and JF for stopping by last night.Â It was great to see you. In terms of random bar events, nothing too bizarre went on last evening.Â My favorite part of the night was when this random woman came in at 3:25, and she wanted a drink.Â Then, she began to try to tell me some sort of story thatÂ involved her cell mate, her birthday, and robbery.Â Hmmm... However, Penny was also witness to some of the regular events that make the bar the ghetto place that it is.Â After 2:30 Bergen takes over the music which means that she plays one or two songs repeatedly.Â Â Last night, her favorite was Rod Stewart's BROKEN ARROW.Â I swear to God, that Bergen, Penny, random drunk men at the bar, and I were singing our hearts out to this Stewart classic. Second favorite comment by Jack:Â Upon meeting JF, he burst into some song that had her name in it.Â Ahh... Jack.Â You're so romantic. Favorite Jack comment:Â A weird, dirty guy in a tight tank top kissed him.Â He came over to the bar and told us that he didn't like that.Â Jack then proceeded to say, "I maybe poor, but I am clean.Â I take two showers a day."Â Ahh... Jack.Â You're so romantic. Bergen told this manager from another bar that I am the best bartender that she knows (blatant lie).Â Then, she told them that I can pour four bottles at once (another lie).Â That last one didn't work out too well though because they then asked to see me do this.Â So, I had to go back behind the bar, and give it a shot.Â I actually was able to do it, but I don't think that I looked too confident in my attempt.Â The whole bar cheered when I didnt' break anything. So that's the news.Â I hope that everything is going well with all of you, and I'll talk to you later.

FROM 8/20/03: How are you this morning?Â I hope that you are all well.Â It's Wednesday morning-- We're halfway there. Last night was an average night at the bar.Â Â The highlight of the night was having Bergen back.Â She has been on vacation for the past two weeks in Spain.Â She came back to the bar in all of her glory, and even managed to get me a present.Â She bought me a black shawl.Â Very nice. The most memorable thing about work last evening was the gross behavior of the women at the bar.Â Sometimes, it really boggles the mind.Â I'll break it down.Â First, a couple comes in.Â Â The man is named Jimmy and he is a trader in his 50s.Â The woman is named Wanda, and she is in her 30s.Â As far as I can tell, her occupation may involve using men for their money, but more on that later.Â Anyway, they sat in the corner and consumed a LARGE amount of alcohol.Â I think that she had five martinis.Â After two hours, they were all over each other at the bar.Â Fine.Â That's no problem.Â Then, Wanda goes to use the rest room, and Jimmy uses that opportunity to tell me all about his life.Â He's been married.Â He has three kids.Â He travels all the time, yada, yada, yada.Â Then, he throws outÂ the fact that stuff like this with younger women never lasts.Â Uh... okay.Â Thanks for sharing with me, Jimmy.Â I had to shush him so Wanda wouldn't hear what he was talking about. Eventually, the two of them leave, and I breathe a sigh of relief.Â After about two to three hours, Wanda comes back.Â Jimmy is gone, and she is dragging one of her girlfriends around with her.Â She's still plastered, and she orders drinks for herself and her friend.Â Then, she begins to talk to the only guys at the bar.Â The first man that she corners is a man I mentally refer to as old, scary wine guy.Â That's probably because he is old, scary, and he drinks one glass of wine and leaves.Â Before I know it, he is feeling her up at the bar.Â Wonderful.Â There's nothing like a little soft porn to spice up your night.Â Eventually, he tells her that he has to go, and she gives him her number. Now, Wanda is left with only one feasible male option-Â Hugo.Â Before I know it, Hugo is throwing me $50 and telling me to save his beer and not to cash him out.Â The two of them head out the door holding hands.Â Hugo returns alone around 3:00.Â He doesn't comment on what happens and only says that, "People can be disgusting."Â I cannot even imagine what transpired to make Hugo say something like that. Another woman who makes me ashamed of my gender is named Shanshee (sp?).Â I have seen her in ther bar a few times before with one of the old owners, Artie.Â She is about 22, and Artie is in his late 40s.Â I always thought that they were a couple, but I think that I may have been wrong.Â Apparently, Shanshee is engaged to a different 45 year-old man.Â Hmmm... She told me that she was going to her fiancee's daughter's wedding in a couple of weeks, and his daughter is a week younger than her.Â She kept asking me what she should wear.Â At one point, I realized that I was counseling her not to go with her original suggestion of wearing red.Â Then, I realized that I was wasting my breath even talking to her, and just agreed that she should wear her short red dress, and that it was okay even though the bridemaids were wearing red too.Â I hope that the daughter chews her up and spits her out.Â Did I mention that Shanshee tipped meÂ $1? The final disgrace to womanhood was the crazy, middle-aged smoker woman.Â Literally, this woman was a chimney.Â She had to finish a pack in the two hours that she was there.Â She came in with two men that worked with her.Â Here were some of her best comments of the night: Crazy lady to co-workers:Â You guys are just too young for me.Â Sorry.Â I can't do it. Crazy lady to American co-worker:Â Feel these babies.Â They still stay up on their own. Crazy lady to foreign co-worker: You're not circumcised??Â I am never going down there. Foreign co-worker:Â What are you talking about?Â It is beautiful. Crazy Lady: I'm sorry, but there's nothing worse in life than a small pen#s. Foreign co-worker: No, it's okay, if he knows how to use it. Crazy Lady:Â Honey, that's just a lie.Â But let's ask everyone else at the bar what they think. Crazy Lady to me when I asked if I could have my pen back:Â Are you calling me a pen thief?!? To top it all off, the woman left her cell at the bar.Â Someone called it, so I picked it up.Â It was the crazy lady's daughter, and she kept asking me where her mother was.Â I felt like saying, "Well, I don't know, but don't worry: One of the guys she is with is uncircumcised." That''s the news, and I'm Outta Here

FROM 6/25/03: Let me give you a hypothetical situation.Â Would you ever go into a bar, when they are closing, demand a drink, and then tell the bartender that you were willing to "sign a napkin," because you are the owner's friend, and the owner wouldn't expect real payment?Â Well, this is what happened last night around four.Â Not only was my bank counted out, but it was already separated into neatly-labeled envelopes and ready to be dropped.Â Kit, a guy who I have seen in the bar once or twice, honestly thought that I was going to give him another drink, not make him pay, and then hang around and shoot the sh#t with him until he finished.Â And this wasn't a single, timid request he made.Â He tried to convince me to do this for about ten minutes.Â Of course these had to be the ten precious minutes from 3:50 until 4:00... ten minutes I could have been asleep.Â I tried to tell him very politely that my bar was closed.Â But he said that the upstairs bartender had sent him down to my bar (mental note:Â never speak to the upstairs bartender, again!).Â My fatigue at the end of the night is so great that I am completely unintimidated by a customer's size.Â By the end of the conversation I was shouting at this very large man that I had been up for 20 hours, and I absolutely would not give him a cocktail.Â He had to settle for writing an angry letter to our owner... ON A BEVERAGE NAPKIN.Â I know that I always take letters written on table linens very seriously.Â Crackhead... The highlight of my night had to do with Jack.Â I believe that I have mentioned how much Jack loves my roommate.Â Well, my friends, that is no more.Â Jack told me that he has "fired" her, and that I am the new love of his life. Â Now I don't know exactly what this will entail, but, so far, I have gotten an extra large carton of Pringles from the deli across the street.Â Honestly, at three a.m., there is nothing more romantic. I usually use these recaps to make fun of my customers, but I have been known to do many stupid things myself.Â Last night, when shaking two tequila shots to chill them, I realized that I didn't have the shaker together properly, and tequila flew all over my shirt and into my eye.Â Now, a smooth bartender would have pretended that nothing had happened.Â I chose to yell at the top of my lungs, "I'm blind.Â I'm blind."Â Tom Cruise from Cocktail, I am not. I would like to give a big shout-out (Come one, when was the last time you heard the word shout-out in a sentence?) to my roommate for coming in last night. She made the trek to the den of sin around 11 with Seth.Â Way to go! I guess the most picturesque moment of the evening occurred around 3.Â Bergen and I were playing her R. Kelly CD for the fifth time.Â And if it was the 5th time for the CD, it was the 20th time for the song, "Ignition."Â I looked up at my bar, and I saw that everyone was dancing in harmony.Â There were two, white powerful lawyers busting a move in their Ron Howard-like way.Â There was Heavy (thus named for his heavy metal band in Japan), and his Asian friends sort of bobbing their friends.Â There were African American bartenders from down the street dressed in their super-fly style and busting a move.Â Â I guess I only have one thing to say-- My bar:Â bringing the world of drunks together.
